reviewText:
Dinner Date is a very short indie title about a man waiting for his date to arrive and I ♥♥♥♥ing hated it.

The main reason I hated this game was mainly due to the usual false expectations scenario. Rather than just completely rip this game apart let me explain what I thought the game was going to be, and then what the game actually is.

What I thought Dinner Date was going to be:

Everything I thought this game was going to be came from what people posted about on the internet. Nothing I am writing in this section is what I hoped the game would be, this is what I expected based on others experiences with it. Like I mentioned above, this is a game about a man waiting for his date to arrive at his house. However, I was under the assumption that this would be 1st person, without any narration, and you are completely free to do whatever you want while you wait for the date. You do not know who the date is, or why this man is possibly being stood up. Maybe this is him being dumped, maybe he murdered her, maybe he doesn’t have a date and he’s lonely, we just don’t know. While waiting for your possible date to arrive, you are free to do whatever you want in your apartment. Doing actions will affect the outcome of “The Date”. Maybe you could eat your entire meal before he/she shows up, would that have an effect? Maybe if you drink the whole bottle of wine you will pass out and miss the date entirely, never knowing if the person came by or not. Maybe you could just sit there and wait the entire time, twiddling your thumbs, eagerly watching the clock. Maybe you could just ♥♥♥♥ing kill yourself, the point is what sold me on this game was mystery. Every time I looked into this game online, for whatever reason, the game was completely shrouded in mystery, and this made me want to play the game so badly. I was honestly expecting to play this game multiple times just to see what else I could make happen. There could’ve been so many possibilities, so many outcomes, but as you can guess I ended up being tremendously disappointed.

What Dinner Date actually is:

A monologue. The game is literally just a monologue disguised as a video game. If there are any David Cage fanboys reading this, buy this game right now. NOTHING you do while you “wait” for you date matters. I only played this game once and I went in with the intention of killing my character through alcohol abuse, but even though I am drinking down a glass of wine every 5 seconds, the character doesn’t shut up…even while he is drinking. You are forced to listen to this guy whine and complain and there’s nothing you can do about it. Yeah, there are actions, but they are ♥♥♥♥ing meaningless. I’m pretty sure if someone smoked 47 cigarettes in a row he would maybe cough a few times in the middle of his ♥♥♥♥♥ing. The game kept giving me hope that something good would happen. Oh look! He’s getting up! Can I jump out the window? Nope. Can I open my fridge? Nope. Well, can I grab that endless bottle of wine again? Not right now, nope. When I realized that I could just sit back and the game would play itself I decided to stick through to the end, with the hope that maybe something interesting would happen, but of course not. You listen to this guy whine and complain about life for awhile and then that’s it, it just ends. He doesn’t kill himself (sadly), the date never shows up, nothing ♥♥♥♥ing happens. The best part about the uh experience is the torture is short. My game time for this is 23 minutes and I waiting till the credits ended.

So that’s it, I can’t even recommend this game to people who enjoy monologues, or hearing sad..ish life stories. Rather that waste your time listening to this guys issue’s you could go hang out with your friends, and maybe help them with their problems. I can promise in that situation different outcomes and functionality that makes an impact, I dare you to try and drink as much wine as I did in this game while hearing your friend talk. In other words, real life is more of a video game than Dinner Date.

reviewText:
Dinner Date is a first person experience that puts you into someone's subconscious. You'll see what he sees and hear his thoughts as he waits for his date and you'll push keys. The key prompts float in little bubbles that have hints about what they'll do. Different keys do different things. You'll get to pour a glass of wine, look at the clock, check your left hand and gaze at your right hand. There are even such details like putting your spoon into soup, stirring it, put the spoon back down and so on. You'll hear the character talk, basically telling you which of the things to do next.

Going into the game I thought it would be another 'crazy hand simulator' like Surgeon Simulator or Ampu-Tea. Nope, you just press keys to do things when the prompts are up.

You have no control over movement or the camera, just over what the character does as he continues to worry about his date. He will wonder whether to drink another glass of wine and what else he could be doing. The dinner date is a quick experience, over in about 30 minutes. Trying to replay it again didn't lead me to think that there are different outcomes.

Dinner Date has a lot going for it, the voice acting is good, the environment is great, but its just a small kitchen with a table in it. You'll go to the window to have a cigarette, but that's it. This could be the demo of a bigger more detailed game, there is talent here, but I just didn't have fun playing the game. Plus there's not much here to get excited about. Its over quick. If a bobbing camera gets you motion sick, avoid this game.

Here's something to think about when telling a story. If its not the most interesting thing that happens to the character,  why aren't you telling the more interesting story? Is it technical limitations such as having characters to interact with? Is this what leads the character up to his suicide or finding his true love after the game has ended? Is it witty banter amongst two characters blended with subconscious thought? No, but maybe that will happen in Dinner Date 2: The Reckoning. I'm sure that Luke Skywalker had moments where he just chilled in his bedroom thinking about a girl. That never made it into Star Wars.

Dinner Date was just watching something while I mash all keys at once since there's no sort of right or wrong. Other narrative experiences like Dear Esther and Gone Home at least give you movement control and environments to explore. Like the plot of Dinner Date, it stands in a category all its own.

reviewText:
Dinner Date is not a game. That is to say, loading it up and playing it doesn't expose you to anything you might consider gameplay. It is an intellectual experiment, trying to create art from a gaming perspective. Unfortunately what comes out is something that is so pretentious it seems to have been sucked through it's own rear end and into a completely different reality.

Now, if this was a free to download and try experiment at merging gaming and art I probably would be more positive towards it. But this is a priced experience, you don't simply get to try something new, you have to pay for it. And you don't get much for your money.

You play as Julian Luxemburg, or rather, as his subconscious as he sits around, nervously waiting for his date to arrive, you get to hear his inner monologue, fidget with the various items on the table and drum your fingers a bit. And that's really it, that's the entire experience. The subtle differences that can occur from taking different actions are so minute that it's hardly worth a second playthrough.

Only bright side to this experience is the above average voice acting of Julian but that alone doesn't add much.

All in all, this is quite simply a travesty. I am all for game developers experimenting and trying new things but when you are charging me money for 10 minutes of listening to someone worry about life that's just attempting to cash in on the bizarreness of your creation. Do not buy this, it is not worth your time and even if you're into this sort of art, there are much better experiences outside of the gaming medium.

The game lures you into thinking it's going to be like surgeon simulator, explaining hand controls using 'q w e r' for the movement of each finger, and 'g' for the thumb. From thereout you will continue to pointlessly press buttons and observe the mundane animation. My favorite part has to be where you are granted the option to dip your bread into the soup you've been stirring for 10 minutes.

The game ends when your character staggers out of the apartment after a few glasses of wine, presumably to perform some kind of aggressive crime against the elusive date. This means you basically miss the most exciting part of the protagonists evening.

1/10. There is no challenge, no excitement, and no respite from the ball-achingly dull key tapping. Only play this game if someone has a gun to your head.

reviewText:
Truly groundshattering. Though I beat the game in 20 minutes, I could easily see myself playing this game for more than 300 hours. The game has amazing replay value, and though your decisions do not change the ending, every playthrough will leave you wondering what you could have done differently.

The game confidently struts into morally gray areas and makes you question your own ethics. The challenge is in deciding whether you should continue, or simply end your miserable evening. Should you have another glass of wine? A seemingly mundane decision, but one that carries world-altering repercussions in this game. Can you resist the temptation of double-dipping your bread, and potentially contaminating your soup? Could you handle the thought of lying to your date about your double dipping habits, should you choose to travel down the path of ultimate sauce corruption? Such maddening thoughts would bring dread to the most stalwart of dinner-havers.

The horrific potential consequences of your actions are bound to keep you up for many nights. Did you do the right thing? Maybe you gazed at the clock one too many times, causing irreparable damage to your neck. Perhaps you chose to forego cooling your soup slightly and burned the roof of your mouth. Maybe you even did that on purpose; the masochistic behavior of a true non-conforming renegade. Yes, it's true, that you knew the whole time you were shoving piece of bread after piece of bread into your mouth that you were dancing with death. Like a marionette, swaying to the symphony of the all-powerful carbohydrates; their promise of deliciousness cleverly luring your naive and all-too-trusting mind into a false sense of security. Little did you know the grossly unhealthy nutritional value of these baked goods would chaperone you to an early grave.

There is no end to the madness. I strongly recommend you buy this game and experience its haunting story-telling on your own. If you think you have a good understanding of how your subconscious mind works, and feel that you are in complete control over your actions and its consequences, then prepare to have your illusory world of make-believe completely ♥♥♥♥ing shattered.

reviewText:
DINNER DATE.
Stout Games, 2011

Genres: Casual, Indie, Sad ♥♥♥ Simulator

Plot: The player assumes the role of Julian Luxemburg, a vaguely British man on a DINNER DATE with a beautiful Japanese woman.

Actually, that was a lie. You don’t assume the role of Julian Luxemburg, a vaguely British man on a date with a beautiful Japanese woman. You actually assume the role of Julian Luxemburg’s subconscious. And you’re actually being stood up by a beautiful Japanese woman. And you actually never see her, so she’s probably not that beautiful. Whether or not she’s even Japanese, I have my doubts.

Anyway, you “play” the game as Julian’s subconscious. What does that mean exactly? It means you don’t actually get full control of your character. Instead, you’re in charge of “the small unconscious actions we all do”--things like making Julian look at his hand, or look at his other hand, or touch his face. You do not, by the way, get to do any of the cool things a subconscious can do, like give Julian the sudden urge to kill or make him have a nightmare about his naked father. No, but you can make him mindlessly snack on a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of bread. And before you start to think that your actions can affect the outcome in the game whatsoever, you’re wrong. Nothing you do matters at all. You could do nothing or everything and nothing would change. To be fair, the game tells you this pretty much right away, so good on them.

So, you sit there for awhile doing random meaningless ♥♥♥♥ and Julian gets progressively drunker and more depressed as he rambles and whines on and on about his life as a total ♥♥♥♥ing loser and then, after 20 minutes of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, he decides to leave his apartment and the game ends and you feel angry but also a little relieved that it’s over. The end.

Gameplay: What the game lacks in fun stuff, it makes up for in not fun stuff, such as stirring soup, looking at a clock, quoting Lord Byron, and constant whining.

Realism: As I said, you get stood up by your date and spend the evening getting drunk alone while succumbing to crippling doubt and insecurity. I don’t know what that’s like because I’m handsome. 0/10.

Graphics: I had the game set on “exorbitant graphical quality” but my character's fingers looked like mangled dongs.

Overall score: 3 out of 10 stars, which makes sense considering I paid 3 out of 10 dollars for the game.

On the whole this game really isn't worth it. It's an interesting concept, and the voice acting is interesting... but if you have to miss an out there indie game this year, this is the one to miss.

I just got Steam-Trolled with this game.
To call this art would be a travesty against artists that put their time and soul into their work. This feels more like a school project where only the minimum requirements were met and the assignment was worked on at the very last minute.  I can picture the requirements now:
1.	Game must contain real-time graphics – check
2.	Game must contain human interaction – check
3.	Game must contain at least 15 minutes of gameplay –check
Left off the list of requirements were fun, meaningful gameplay, script, and direction. This would have required some additional thought on the creator’s part and it’s just not something that could be bothered with.
There’s a warning right off that you are not playing … well, that’s as far as you need to read because there is no gameplay. Hitting keys on the keyboard will cause your character to look at different points of the screen as the events unfold. You’re greeted with a completely unintelligible and unscripted narration which meanders frequently and even manages to be a bit racist.  Apparently, you suffer from both Parkinson’s disease and attention deficit disorder since the camera is constantly faffing about. The entirety of the “game” doesn’t require your input and will automatically unfold even if you decide not to interact with it. Yes, this is a “game” that you don’t even have to play.
This is a product which can only be considered art by those who don’t know what art actually is. It’s like having a friend that extols the virtue of paintings of dogs playing poker.  If you’re one of these people that believes this is art or there’s some meaningful message hidden away to be examined with methodical thought then please just refrain from pretending to be a contributing member of society.
Stay as far away from this as you possibly can. Even the time you have taken to read through this regarding this work is time better spent generating dander or turning food into waste. Actually, that action produces something more valuable than this so I would encourage you to perform that.

reviewText:
What can I say? This is a wonderfully crafted game. Well, it's not much of a game, more like a story. A short one, but it's very sweet.

Story - [10/10]
You are in the skin of Julian Luxemburg. You are just the average guy, who is trying to impress a girl via a date. However, your date seems to be late. You sit there, waiting for her. You start drinking the wine and eating the food that you have painstakingly readied for your date. You sit. And wait... It feels realistic and isn't over the top.

Gameplay - [6/10]
The story plays out in a first person perspective, which really involves you into the character. You do not directly control the movement of the character like in other games; instead you get a slu of buttons that you can press, with icons attached to them, telling you what those buttons do. Unfortunately, it is often hard to make out what the buttons display and you might choose an option that you didn't want. You do nothing else, really. That is the whole thing.

Graphics - [7/10]
The colors look very beautiful and the props look good. The texture quality is also very nice. However, the character's hands look pretty low-poly, that could've been prevented. Also, the graphic settings presented are pretty extensive for such a small game! But do the graphics hold up with todays standards? No, but it doesn't look bad by any means.

Sound - [9/10]
The sounds blend in very well with the visuals (for example, you can constantly hear a clock ticking in the background), as does the music. The music isn't out of place at all. The main character sounds very pleasing, but you might have some trouble understanding him, due to his brittish accent. But there is a subtitle option anyways, so yeah.

Conclusion
The game is short, and the gameplay is limited. But what did you come to expect from a game where you wait for your date? Sure, the concept of the game is pretty strange, but the way it tells the story is spot-on. It really spoke to me. The gameplay is also spot-on for what it's trying to present, but it's not very challenging or intuitive. If you do not mind spending 3 bucks on a small 20 - 30 minute adventure, then I can only recommend it. Especially when it's on a discount.

I rate this game with a [7/10], but it is only recommended for those who don't mind simple gameplay and a short play-time. I am open to discuss this review, feel free to comment.

reviewText:
Okay. So, this game is extremely short. And for the 20 minutes that it takes to be beaten, 3€ might be too expansive. I got it when it was on sale and I would recommend too wait for the next one.

“Dinner Date” is a very interesting gaming experience, mostly because of the basic idea: You don’t play the character, you play his subconscious. You are not able to change anything, the story will always come to the same end. But in your position in the back of his mind, you are the only one, who can clearly see what is going on. You are the one who witnesses the metamorphosis from a lightly desperate, but kind man to a misogynist, slightly racist ♥♥♥♥.

The mechanics might be disappointing from a purely mechanical point of view, but they are much more than in most games not only the vehicle to get the story further, but part of the storytelling. The fact, that the game is able to play itself without you as your strange incapacity to change anything, but to play on, is not only a fancy mechanic, it IS the story that you witness.

“Dinner Date” messes a lot of expectations up, that you have in games and gives a whole new view on how game mechanics and narrations really work and what makes them up.

reviewText:
I'm often a fan of experimental and artistic games, and this one certainly has its merits, but I do not think it is worth even the small price of £2.79.  The main issue, as many have mentioned, is the length.  It is a very short experience indeed, and unlike, say, The Stanley Parable, it has no replay value at all.  The player has no control over the narrative; there are some controls you can use to look around, idly fiddle with stuff and such, but the narrative will soldier on whatever you do, or indeed, even if you do nothing.  That's a shame; a veneer of 'immersion' with no substance.  It's very clear that the game is pretty much made by one person; I'm not sure whether it was a university project, but it does seem like one.  The graphics aren't amazing, even on the highest settings I felt like Julian was made of papier mâché, and the story all takes place in one small room, so most of the work clearly went into the script, and most of the budget to the voice acting.

The story itself is poignant and relatable, though the main character occasionally jars the relatability with a racist comment or a crude but oddly coy internal discussion about sex.  The voice acting is quite good, but occasionally clashes with the script creating an odd dissonance between the actor and the writer.  If only the actor had felt able to paraphrase and improvise a little, it might have come off more naturally.

Play it if it's free; buy it if you're interested and it's at least 50% off in a sale.  That isn't rare.  I feel depressed after playing it, but that's because it sometimes reminded me of myself and my own internal monologue, and it does this well.  If only the character were even more relatable, I could recommend this more heartily.

reviewText: [...] Dinner Date's focus on methodically destroying any old fixed point in video games can be seen as a cry for freedom and renewal by the hand of one of the first avant-garde movements born within the video game medium, whose birth, to tell the truth, is maybe more exact to retrace to Tale of Tales' Realtime Art Manifesto (Harvey and Samyn, 2006) from which even Stout admitted to have taken inspiration (Stout, 2011a). Although this is not the absolutely first video-game related clear avant-garde movement (even the clarity of it it's arguable, since it is surely not the Harvey and Samyn's manifesto that connects the many non-game, or to be more precise anti-games, that were released in the last four to five years), as we may remember other examples like the demoscene (Scheib et al., 2002), it is surely the first that has bled so fast and directly into the mainstream, with products like Journey (that also tries to put the player in a position of anti-power) or the Telltale Games' adaptation of The Walking Dead (that, together with David Cage's games, makes immediately clear that its protagonist is not an embodiment nor an extension of the player). If this is a true desire for change by an industry tired of the tropes that get reiterated from years and years, or just a temporary fluke, it is not for us to predict. But one thing is sure, and that is that, in its destruction of tropes, Jeroen D. Stout with Dinner Date managed to find a different and intriguing approach to interactive art and story-telling, that is worth to be taken a look at and studied even now, three years after its release.\n\nFull Article: http://www.scriptaludica.com/2014/10/dinner-date-subverting-tropes-of.html

reviewText:
I want to be able to recommend Dinner Date - it's definitely one of the more unique game experiences to be found on Steam - but too early into it, you realize that you've experienced just about all the game has to offer, and you're left slogging through monologue after monologue waiting for things to move on.

I went into this game knowing absolutely nothing about it. I received it as a gift, and had not heard of it prior. I expected it to be a lame dating simulator, and it's probably the best praise I can give to say that it is not that. Instead, you play as the inner subconscious mind of young-ish man who's set up his small kitchen for a date. As he sits at the table and waits for his date arrive, you can influence his actions by focusing on different parts of the scene, all while listening to the man's thoughts as the night grows later and later.

Unfortunately, this gets monotonous very quickly, and you're stuck following a very linear path as you pick your way through all the interactive parts of the scene. It also becomes very obvious early into the experience what will happen, which doesn't help the game feel more like work than play.

It's too bad, because the premise is interesting, and it could have been enjoyable, even if only as an art piece. As it stands however, Dinner Date is too slow and predictable to be any fun, in my opinion.
